verses.text: Jesus left the temple and was going away when his disciples came to point out to him the buildings of the temple.
verses.comment: The disciples’ amazement emphasizes the grandeur of the temple. This sets up Jesus’ significant prophecy about its destruction.

verses.text: But he answered them, 'Do you see all these? Truly, I say to you, there will not be left here one stone upon another that will not be thrown down.'
verses.comment: Jesus predicts the temple’s destruction, fulfilled in A.D. 70. This shows his prophetic authority and hints at a new spiritual worship (see John 4:21-24).

verses.text: As he sat on the Mount of Olives, the disciples came to him privately, saying, 'Tell us, when will these things happen, and what will be the sign of your coming and of the end of the age?'
verses.comment: The disciples link the temple’s destruction with the end times—a common belief then. Jesus’ reply has both immediate (Roman destruction) and future (final coming) fulfillment.

verses.text: Jesus answered them, 'Take care that no one leads you astray.'
verses.comment: Warning of deception—many will claim false authority. The need for steadfastness in true teaching is implied.

verses.text: 'For many will come in my name, saying, "I am the Christ," and they will lead many astray.'
verses.comment: False messiahs troubled the early Church; genuine believers are called to discern Christ’s true presence by fidelity to apostolic teaching.

verses.text: 'You will hear of wars and rumors of wars. See that you are not alarmed; for this must take place, but the end is not yet.'
verses.comment: Christ counsels perseverance. External turmoil is not the sign; the true disciple trusts the divine plan.

verses.text: 'For nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom, and there will be famines and earthquakes in various places.'
verses.comment: Typical apocalyptic imagery; such troubles are only the birth pains. Old Testament echoes remind us of God’s sovereignty.

verses.text: 'But all these are the beginning of birth pains.'
verses.comment: The metaphor of birth points to suffering leading to new life and restoration.

verses.text: 'Then they will deliver you up to tribulation and put you to death, and you will be hated by all nations for my name’s sake.'
verses.comment: Christ predicts the persecution of his followers. Early martyrs fulfilled this prophecy, and it points to the Church’s suffering as a mark of fidelity.

verses.text: 'And then many will fall away and betray one another and hate one another.'
verses.comment: Apostasy and betrayal are foretold. Staying united and not judging one another is highlighted as essential.

verses.text: 'And many false prophets will rise up and lead many astray.'
verses.comment: It’s important to follow authentic teaching passed through the apostles. False teachers are a threat in every age.

verses.text: 'And because lawlessness will be increased, the love of many will grow cold.'
verses.comment: Christians are called to perseverance in charity even in hard times. Spiritual decline is a real danger.

verses.text: 'But the one who endures to the end will be saved.'
verses.comment: The necessity of perseverance and faithfulness is emphasized. Salvation is an ongoing process to be completed at the end.

verses.text: 'And this gospel of the kingdom will be proclaimed throughout the whole world as a testimony to all nations, and then the end will come.'
verses.comment: Evangelization is necessary before the end. The mission is global, in continuity with Israel’s role as light to the nations.

verses.text: 'So when you see the abomination of desolation, spoken of by the prophet Daniel, standing in the holy place (let the reader understand),'
verses.comment: This prophecy refers to sacrilege in the temple (cf. 1 Macc. 1:54) and anticipates the final desecration—layers of fulfillment.

verses.text: 'then let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains.'
verses.comment: A practical warning: Jesus cares for his followers’ physical safety. The initial fulfillment was in A.D. 70.

verses.text: 'Let the one who is on the housetop not go down to take what is in his house,'
verses.comment: Jesus urges haste—do not delay when God’s warnings come. This foregrounds the importance of spiritual readiness.

verses.text: 'and let the one who is in the field not return to take his cloak.'
verses.comment: Urgency is stressed. The true disciple must value following Christ above possessions.

verses.text: 'And woe to those who are pregnant and to those who are nursing infants in those days!'
verses.comment: Jesus’ compassion for the vulnerable is clear. His foreknowledge reflects his divine care.

verses.text: 'Pray that your flight may not be in winter or on a Sabbath.'
verses.comment: Jesus respects the Sabbath, hinting at continuity with God’s sacred times.

verses.text: 'For then there will be great tribulation, such as has not been from the beginning of the world until now, no, and never will be.'
verses.comment: The tribulation is both historic and eschatological—a double fulfillment is implied.

verses.text: 'And if those days had not been cut short, no human being would be saved. But for the sake of the elect those days will be cut short.'
verses.comment: God’s mercy protects the elect. Election is God’s initiative, but perseverance is required.

verses.text: 'Then if anyone says to you, “Look, here is the Christ!” or “There he is!” do not believe it.'
verses.comment: Christ’s coming will be unmistakable; secrecy marks falsehood.

verses.text: 'For false christs and false prophets will arise and perform great signs and wonders, so as to lead astray, if possible, even the elect.'
verses.comment: Miraculous signs alone are not proof of truth; faithfulness to apostolic teaching is the safeguard.

verses.text: 'See, I have told you beforehand.'
verses.comment: Forewarning from Christ shows his divine foreknowledge. The faithful are prepared by his words.

verses.text: 'So, if they say to you, “Look, he is in the wilderness,” do not go out. If they say, “Look, he is in the inner rooms,” do not believe it.'
verses.comment: True revelation is public, not hidden. Christ’s real coming will transcend secret sects.

verses.text: 'For as the lightning comes from the east and shines as far as the west, so will be the coming of the Son of Man.'
verses.comment: The return of Christ will be visible to all, leaving no ambiguity.

verses.text: 'Wherever the corpse is, there the vultures will gather.'
verses.comment: A proverbial saying: judgment is inevitable where evil is. This hints at the reality of final judgment.

verses.text: 'Immediately after the tribulation of those days the sun will be darkened, and the moon will not give its light, and the stars will fall from the sky, and the powers of the heavens will be shaken.'
verses.comment: Apocalyptic imagery recalls God’s direct intervention. This connects to prophetic tradition in the Old Testament.

verses.text: 'Then the sign of the Son of Man will appear in heaven, and then all the tribes of the earth will mourn, and they will see the Son of Man coming on the clouds of heaven with power and great glory.'
verses.comment: Jesus applies Daniel 7:13 to himself—a claim to divine authority. All nations witness his coming.

verses.text: 'And he will send out his angels with a loud trumpet call, and they will gather his elect from the four winds, from one end of heaven to the other.'
verses.comment: End-time gathering of the faithful fulfills prophetic expectation of a restored people of God.

verses.text: 'From the fig tree learn this lesson: as soon as its branch becomes tender and puts out leaves, you know that summer is near.'
verses.comment: Christ encourages watchfulness; signs point to the nearness of his coming.

verses.text: 'So also, when you see all these things, you know that he is near, at the very gates.'
verses.comment: Vigilance is essential. God’s visitation is imminent whenever these signs appear.

verses.text: 'Truly, I say to you, this generation will not pass away until all these things take place.'
verses.comment: Possible reference to the destruction of Jerusalem within the apostles’ lifetime. Also points to the Church age as the final era.

verses.text: 'Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will never pass away.'
verses.comment: Christ affirms the absolute authority and permanence of his words—a sign of divinity. Only God’s word is eternal.

verses.text: 'But concerning that day and hour, no one knows, not even the angels of heaven, nor the Son, but the Father only.'
verses.comment: Jesus expresses humility regarding His voluntary self-limitation during the Incarnation (see Phil. 2:7).

verses.text: 'For as were the days of Noah, so will be the coming of the Son of Man.'
verses.comment: The suddenness of the Flood illustrates how judgment will come at Christ’s return.

verses.text: 'For as in those days before the flood they were eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage, until the day Noah entered the ark,'
verses.comment: Normal life lulled people into complacency—Jesus calls us to vigilance.

verses.text: 'and they did not know until the flood came and swept them all away, so will be the coming of the Son of Man.'
verses.comment: Christ compares His return to the sudden judgment of the flood; preparedness is vital.

verses.text: 'Then two men will be in the field; one will be taken and one left.'
verses.comment: This hints at final separation—faithfulness in the midst of daily life is what matters.

verses.text: 'Two women will be grinding at the mill; one will be taken and one left.'
verses.comment: No one knows when; our daily actions have eternal significance.

verses.text: 'Therefore, stay awake, for you do not know on what day your Lord is coming.'
verses.comment: Constant spiritual vigilance is emphasized; faith and good works are both necessary.

verses.text: 'But know this, that if the master of the house had known in what part of the night the thief was coming, he would have stayed awake and not let his house be broken into.'
verses.comment: The unexpected return of Christ parallels a thief in the night. Preparedness is essential.

verses.text: 'Therefore you also must be ready, for the Son of Man is coming at an hour you do not expect.'
verses.comment: The call to readiness is repeated, stressing the importance of continual spiritual vigilance.

verses.text: 'Who then is the faithful and wise servant, whom his master has set over his household, to give them their food at the proper time?'
verses.comment: Christ speaks of leaders (“servants”) with responsibility for dispensing what nourishes. The idea echoes Church leadership and sacramental stewardship.

verses.text: 'Blessed is that servant whom his master will find so doing when he comes.'
verses.comment: Faithful service is praised. Christ’s return will reward those who have continued their stewardship.

verses.text: 'Truly, I say to you, he will set him over all his possessions.'
verses.comment: Eternal reward is proportional to faithfulness in entrusted duties; this hints at a hierarchy among the faithful in the age to come.

verses.text: 'But if that wicked servant says to himself, “My master is delayed,”'
verses.comment: Temptation grows when the Lord seems delayed. The test of true faith is perseverance.

verses.text: 'and begins to beat his fellow servants and eats and drinks with drunkards,'
verses.comment: Faithful leadership requires humility and care for others, not abuse of authority.

verses.text: 'the master of that servant will come on a day when he does not expect him and at an hour he does not know,'
verses.comment: The warning applies especially to those with authority in Christ’s household—a sober call to faithfulness.

verses.text: 'and will cut him in pieces and assign him a place with the hypocrites. In that place there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.'
verses.comment: Judgment is severe for those given responsibility who fail in charity and vigilance. True faith is lived out in both word and deed.
